1.brief: gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
properly, to bend or stoop in kindness to an inferior; to favor, bestow; causatively to implore (i.e. move to favor by petition)
to kneel; by implication to bless God (as an act of adoration), and (vice-versa) man (as a benefit); also (by euphemism) to curse (God or the king, as treason)
to be (causative, make) luminous (literally and metaphorically)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.

2.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
something saved, i.e. (abstractly) deliverance; hence, aid, victory, prosperity

3.brief: physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

4.brief: probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome
properly, to creak (or emit a stridulous sound), i.e. to shout (usually for joy)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock

a level, i.e. a plain (often used (with the article prefix) as a proper name of certain districts); figuratively, concord; also straightness, i.e. (figuratively) justice (sometimes adverbially, justly)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to guide; by implication, to transport (into exile, or as colonists)

a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock

6.brief: the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
produce, i.e. a crop or (figuratively) wealth

to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
cessation, i.e. an end (especially of the earth); often used adverb, no further; also the ankle (in the dual), as being the extremity of the leg or foot
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
